title: Cardano Preserving Culture
description: Digital services for Intellectual Property are not available to Indigenous Communities, excluding them from fair and legal representation.

f6_assessments.q0: This looks like a great idea, using a blockchain to store ownership of physical IP. As the proposers point out however, there are significant hurdles to cross before we even get to the blockchain side of things. Unlike something created digitally and then stored on the block chain. the proposers wish to use the blockchain to store ownership of thing that may have already been around for centuries. The hard part there is ascertaining this ownership in the first place. This proposal acknowledges this fact, and intends to conduct research and consultation to try and figure it out. As such the majority of this project is not really NFT related but focused at a level prior to that. Hence the 3 star rating.
f6_assessments.q1:
It is hard to state it is highly likely this project will be successfully implemented due to the fact as mentioned above that it is reliant on a prior of actually establishing ownership of the IP, which they intend to use this funding to research. Successfully implementation would thus require 
that research to be successful. The proposers, WADA, have great experience with Catalyst in the Africa space and thus they may be able to solve the problem. It would also be good to see a road map going forward of what happens next if this step is successful. Will all future steps require more funding, or is there a business plan to become self sufficient?
f6_assessments.q2: The key metrics reported focus on the number of people engaged with. This seems like a necessary but not sufficient condition for success. The proposers should be focusing on what appears to be the key impediment for this proposal succeeding, which is, can they reliably (and perhaps legally) ascertain ownership of IP for which they then store immutably on the blockchain? Without this there is nothing to store and there is not project. Further metrics would then be the number of items/patterns etc stored, number of people/groups/regions using it, and then onto number of countries etc.
f6_assessments.reply: Contradictory and Unfair Impact/Alignment Note: Assessor gives contradictory reason for low score that this proposal does not belong to this category contrary to his/her own prior statement. Also, it is a well known project management fact that the most successful projects are the ones that starts with a comprehensive exploration of the problem space... therefore this proposal definitely fits in this category. Out of scope Feasibility Note: Assessor is judging feasibilty based on criteria outside of this proposal's scope and also makes confusing reference to proposal not belonging to this categoryreferencing his/her inaccurate Impact Note. Out of Scope Impact Assessment: Again, Assessor is making metrics judgement on someting that we have not set out to do in this pase of the proposal.

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal is intended to create a roadmap for an NFT Platform.
It does not explain in detail why it needs its own platform for the purpose it is used for. Wouldn't it be possible to integrate these use cases into existing platforms and thus explore to what extent the mentioned scenarios can be implemented in reality? The business model that can arise from this is not yet clear and therefore the impact of this proposal is not yet clear.
f6_assessments.q1: Wada has already established itself as a solid player in Catalyst and has assembled a broad and capable team. It can be assumed that the necessary resources and funding are available for this project. From the plan described, it is clear what is to be done with funding in the coming months. As I have already mentioned, however, it is not clear why a separate platform has to be created for the investigation of the use cases mentioned. I understand the project as a proof-of-concept. If the use of the treasury is sustainable for this, the community has to decide. The budget as such is clearly structured. It would be helpful if more was known about the market research methods.
f6_assessments.q2: The roadmap and timeframe are clearly defined. It is also clearly described what a successful implementation will look like. What would be an improvement would be to provide a source to document the progress of the proposal so that the community can monitor it. Overall, however, the proposal is good to audit.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal is of extreme exclusion and importance, because it allows for greater visibility and respect for indigenous communities, which have such a rich and precious culture, but which is often not valued, both for lack of protection and lack of knowledge (of the world exterior to its culture). This proposal fits perfectly with the objectives of the challenge, as it intends to create an NFT platform with the objective of recording and disseminating indigenous culture on a global scale, benefiting both the community and the Cardano ecosystem, as it will integrate new content. Also, we can consider that the proposal is related to the challenges "Grow Africa, Grow Cardano" and "Defi and Microlanding for Africa", because it would greatly benefit the continent.
f6_assessments.q1: Certainly the team that sets out to develop the project is quality. WADA is already known to me, I've analyzed several of their proposals, and I know they are a serious and qualified group that promotes projects in the Cardano ecosystem that relate to the problems of their continent. However, for those unfamiliar with the group, it is good that they have included their linkedin names, roles and profiles. With this, you can get to know each one individually and in depth. On the roadmap and currency division, we have a lot of detailed information about what needs to be done, how and in what order. They are very detailed indeed, for example, they mention that the first place they will implement the proposal is Ghana and they justify this, because they already have a strong presence there and prefer to start small to reduce risks (which in my view is always the ideal posture). The monetary division is mentioned in a less detailed way, but it is enough for us to understand how this part of the proposal works.
f6_assessments.q2: In terms of project tracking, we have the definition of success and the metrics that can be used to analyze it. In this way, the community will be able to follow the project's activities in a simple and direct way, and as it expands. Therefore, I believe that the auditability is perfect, although it is short, it is enough to transmit the security we need to know how the project is going.

f6_assessments.q0: This isna fantastic proposal, one that has the pontential to be deployed in various different cultures. The system is great to take away the middleman in such transactions.
f6_assessments.q1: The WADA group has show great success in delivering quality developments in such areas. And the plan shows a breath of experience to achieve the proposed solution.
f6_assessments.q2: There are key metris, KPIs and a breakdown on how the funds are justifiably used per stage of their solution. Im quite confidebt with their progress auditability.

solution: Bring in local developers on a journey to solve the IP problem among indigenous communities for them to earn more from their craft.
experience: WADA: Skilled team of Cardano Community practitioners and entrepreneurs, located in hubs across Africa and the diaspora
